creator: MegaDAS
title: Ultrasonic Sensor HC-SR04 (Arduino Project)
description: This project guides you on how to use two ultrasonic sensors with an Arduino board to measure distances. It covers the hardware and software aspects, allowing you to experiment and develop your own electronics skills. The project measures the distance between the sensors and an object, displaying the measured distance on the serial monitor and turning on/off an LED based on a distance threshold.
steps: Identify the pins of the HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor (VCC, GND, Trig, Echo).
Understand the operating principle of the ultrasonic sensor: it transmits an ultrasonic wave and detects its reflection to determine the distance to an object.
Generate a 10us pulse through the Trig pin to emit an ultrasonic wave.
Measure the duration taken for the pulse to travel to the object and bounce back using the Echo pin.
Calculate the distance by dividing the measured duration by two and then by 29.1 (speed of sound approximation).
Connect the ultrasonic sensors to the Arduino board using jumper wires and a breadboard.
Connect the VCC and GND pins to the Arduino's power supply (5V and GND respectively).
Connect the Trig and Echo pins to digital pins on the Arduino.
Connect the LEDs with 330-ohm resistors to digital pins to indicate a certain distance.
Run the Arduino IDE and upload the provided code to the Arduino board.
The code will measure the distance using the ultrasonic sensors and display the results on the serial monitor.
The code turns on an LED if the measured distance is less than 10cm and turns it off otherwise.
Move objects in front of the sensors to observe the distance measurements and LED behavior.
